bibl.title: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, May 27, 1948

div1.p: Lyons is glad that Hench enjoyed attending the Hall of Fame Reed ceremony. She will return his material and send him a photograph showing Lawrence and Blossom Reed unveiling Walter Reed's bust.

div1.head: Letter from Bertha L. Lyons to Philip Showalter Hench, May 27, 1948
div1.opener:
Every American is a shareholder in the Hall of Fame
HALL OF FAME : NEW YORK UNIVERSITY
I MADISON AVENUE · NEW YORK IO, N.Y.
27 May 1948.
Telephone: MURRAY HILL 3-4469
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter of the 24th
of May. I am glad that you felt compensated for mak-
ing the trip to New York to witness the Reed ceremony.
It's too bad that so many who attended the Congresses did
not come up to New York for our ceremony, but, as Dr.
Salisbury said, they had had ten days of activities and
were tired and wanted to return to their respective homes.

Early next week I shall set myself to the task
of separating what was returned to me by the printer, and
try to correlate it with what I did not send of the mater-
ial which you sent to me, and then return a good portion
of it to you.

I have just ordered a glossy print showing General
Reed and and Blossom Reed unveiling the bronze of their
father. As soon as I have it copied, I shall be glad to
forward a print to you.
I hope you liked the finished product of the program.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
